body_html: Right that’s what many people say, but I’m still excited to start and set my foot in and see how it goes. Thanks for your good advice and for sharing with me your experience. I might ask more questions in the future – and I hope it’s alright. Best, Shiran From: Tongzhou Wang <notifications@github.com> Reply-To: pytorch/pytorch <reply@reply.github.com> Date: Wednesday, February 14, 2018 at 3:35 PM To: pytorch/pytorch <pytorch@noreply.github.com> Cc: Shiran Dudy <dudy@ohsu.edu>, Mention <mention@noreply.github.com> Subject: Re: [pytorch/pytorch] A bug that appears when running with CUDA and does not when using cpu (#5239) @shiranD<https://github.com/shirand> I actually mean the non GAN setting, but with adversarial loss. For example in style transfer, you may want some thing to be indistinguishable with another, but it's not a generative model. Yes, when I read WGAN paper, I was excited as well. The theory is nice and clean and intuitively makes sense. However, you need to keep in mind that very little of GAN theory applies to real settings. For example, many intuition come from that D is the inner optimizing loop (min-max formulation), but this is nearly never what is done in practice. In the end, due to the lack of a nice and complete theory, the theories and intuitions tell us what we should try and what might work. But we still need to try to see whether it works. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<#5239 (comment)>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AIxwwrsq7CjAVtXHsqeWInRc0nGS_AUXks5tU23EgaJpZM4SFu0B>.
body_text:
Right that’s what many people say, but I’m still excited to start and set my foot in and see how it goes.
Thanks for your good advice and for sharing with me your experience.
I might ask more questions in the future – and I hope it’s alright.
Best,
Shiran

From: Tongzhou Wang <notifications@github.com>
Reply-To: pytorch/pytorch <reply@reply.github.com>
Date: Wednesday, February 14, 2018 at 3:35 PM
To: pytorch/pytorch <pytorch@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Shiran Dudy <dudy@ohsu.edu>, Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [pytorch/pytorch] A bug that appears when running with CUDA and does not when using cpu (#5239)


@shiranD<https://github.com/shirand> I actually mean the non GAN setting, but with adversarial loss. For example in style transfer, you may want some thing to be indistinguishable with another, but it's not a generative model. Yes, when I read WGAN paper, I was excited as well. The theory is nice and clean and intuitively makes sense. However, you need to keep in mind that very little of GAN theory applies to real settings. For example, many intuition come from that D is the inner optimizing loop (min-max formulation), but this is nearly never what is done in practice. In the end, due to the lack of a nice and complete theory, the theories and intuitions tell us what we should try and what might work. But we still need to try to see whether it works.

—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<#5239 (comment)>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AIxwwrsq7CjAVtXHsqeWInRc0nGS_AUXks5tU23EgaJpZM4SFu0B>.
body:
Right that’s what many people say, but I’m still excited to start and set my foot in and see how it goes.
Thanks for your good advice and for sharing with me your experience.
I might ask more questions in the future – and I hope it’s alright.
Best,
Shiran

From: Tongzhou Wang <notifications@github.com>
Reply-To: pytorch/pytorch <reply@reply.github.com>
Date: Wednesday, February 14, 2018 at 3:35 PM
To: pytorch/pytorch <pytorch@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Shiran Dudy <dudy@ohsu.edu>, Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [pytorch/pytorch] A bug that appears when running with CUDA and does not when using cpu (#5239)


@shiranD<https://github.com/shirand> I actually mean the non GAN setting, but with adversarial loss. For example in style transfer, you may want some thing to be indistinguishable with another, but it's not a generative model. Yes, when I read WGAN paper, I was excited as well. The theory is nice and clean and intuitively makes sense. However, you need to keep in mind that very little of GAN theory applies to real settings. For example, many intuition come from that D is the inner optimizing loop (min-max formulation), but this is nearly never what is done in practice. In the end, due to the lack of a nice and complete theory, the theories and intuitions tell us what we should try and what might work. But we still need to try to see whether it works.

—
